SP.P: I hope all will turn to your advantage, Ma∣dam —But, in the mean time, what's the gentle∣man's name whom you are in search of?—Perhaps I may learn where he is, if he's in Valencia?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: His name is Sir Charles Winlove.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Sir Charles Winlove, say you! this increases my misfortunes—Have I foster'd a rival?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Keep your temper, Madam, and stick to what you propos'd; we'll find an after-plot to redeem all.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: She changes colour! what can this mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now you may return to Madrid, and inform Alonzo that his daughter's secur'd in my house, and Sir Charles Winlove in the castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: But, my lord, I han't seen her yet, and therefore can't affirm it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I'll call her then.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: I shou'd rather be glad to see her, so that she might not see me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Hold; there's my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: And with her my lady—for she on her left hand is Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now, can you return with confidence?

SP.SPEAKER: Dieg.
SP.P: I can, my lord; farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My father approaches!

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I'll retire, Madam, while you press my suit to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What makes the lady shun me, Leonora?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Because she's a stranger, and that makes her a little reserv'd, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: D'ye remember my advice this morning, daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now my fears!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now, Leonora, you may see the effect of making private assignations unknown to a father— and of exposing a reputation, and the honour of a family—What d'ye think will be the consequence of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Of what, my lord!—I am discover'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Recollect the adventures of this morning, and then you may guess at my meaning.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I see my stratagems are in vain—My lord, too well I understand you—And therefore throw me at your feet.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: She has discover'd all! what shall we do now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What do you mean! Are you at cross-pur∣poses, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My lord, I beg you hear me, and perhaps I may give you satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
Rise then; and if you intend to give me
satisfaction, let it be in a reasonable answer—What makes you in this confusion?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Are you so touch'd with yonder lady's misfor∣tunes, that you kneel in her behalf?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha, I am amaz'd! what an unexpected turn is here.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: The governor fixes his eyes on me!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I am glad you are so good-natur'd, Leonora! for tho' that lady is a prisoner, she is the daughter of my dearest friend, and therefore I'd have her us'd with singular respect.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Am I in my senses! or do I dream!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Courage, Madam; all's well again.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I had like to have betray'd myself by my timorous folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: The governor approaches—I hope she has succeeded.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! here comes another turn of discovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Madam, you are welcome to my house— I know your quality, and am sorry for this accident.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My lord, I thank you—You see me here a stranger in this place—therefore, to raise your pity to my misfortunes, give me leave to relate their particulars.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! if she talks, she betrays all—And then we shall be entirely undone.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I know your story already, Madam—Our histories are full of such amorous adventures—but I question not, but your's will shortly have a happy end—In the mean time, this house shall rather be your sanctuary than consinement—Daughter, I re∣commend this lady to your conversation.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Excellently come off!

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I find, Madam, by my success, that you have pleaded strongly in my behalf.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I even kneel'd to my father to serve you, and am glad it has lain in my power.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I thank you, Madam—I shall never forget such obligations—You'll excuse me for retiring, for I am impatient till I have writ an account of my success to Theodosia.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: It goes according to our wish—My father supposes 'twas her he seiz'd with Sir Charles; and she knows nothing of her being a prisoner, but is pleas'd with her confinement.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: The end must crown all, Madam—And if you can carry on the mistake—'twill be excellent indeed! But how d'ye intend to proceed?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Suppose I write to Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Consider, Madam, what you do.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: You are the first servant that ever was against a lover—You see we are come well off—In love, as in gaming, if we can make a shift to save ourselves, the hopes of winning is a temptation to play on.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: But, Madam, a little luck is commonly a rook, that draws young gamesters in to their de∣struction.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
A lucky cast is seldom won by a faint heart— Love is a lottery, and therefore—
As ventures only can our fortunes frame,
Those who will nothing stake no prize can claim.

DIV3.HEAD: ACT III. SCENE I.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Lorenzo and Don Philip meeting.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: MY lord, you're well met—I am glad I have the good fortune to light on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Have you wanted me on any urgent occa∣sion? Pray what may be the business?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I have an humble petition to your lord∣ship, and you must promise me to grant it, before I tell the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: That's very fine indeed! that I must give my consent, and not know to what—I suppose this is something in relation to my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: No, my lord; what I come now to request is in behalf of a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Be it as it will, Don Philip may command me in any thing, as far as the rules of honour will permit.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I hope, my lord, I shall never be so ungenerous as to require any thing that wou'd be a stain to your honour—but my petition to you is in behalf of Sir Charles Winlove, an English gentle∣man, who I am inform'd your lordship sent this day a prisoner to the castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: D'ye know him?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Very well, my lord, and know him to be a man of honour—I ow'd my life to him when I was in England—and ever after there was such a friendship between us, that during my continuance there we were seldom or never asunder.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I am glad to hear so honourable a character of the gentleman—I am sorry for his misfortunes; but he has injur'd a particular friend of mine in relation to his daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P:
My lord, that proceeds from the wild∣ness of his youth—we are all subject to such faults—Sir Charles is what we esteem a fine gen∣tleman; and the English are all men of gallantry and intrigue—Besides, if a young lady is inclinable
to be kind, what brisk cavalier can refuse her fa∣vours?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I wish I cou'd serve him with honour.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: You may: consider, to confine a young gentleman from his pleasures, is blasting him in the bloom of his life—Besides, liberty is the very soul of the English, and they had rather submit to ho∣honourable death, than bondage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What can I do in this affair?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: If your lordship will allow him to be a prisoner at large, till you hear farther from Madrid, my honour shall be the pledge for his security.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I shou'd be willing to consent to this, were I to follow my own inclinations—but his commit∣ment to the castle is for murder.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My lord, I know the circumstances of the story, and the people concern'd in't, except the young lady—therefore, if you ll believe me, when I left Mdrid, the wounded cavalier was not actually dead—nay, there was some hopes of his recovery.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I had no such intimation in the letter I re∣ceiv'd this morning—but now I think on't, my friend may write so, because I shou'd secure his daughter—Are you sure of this?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Upon my honour, my lord, I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
Then for once I'll yield to your desires—
Follow me, and I'll give you my signet—The keeper knowing you, will obey you at the sight of it—But remember I put my honour into your hands, there∣fore use it with discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My lord, you may depend on it—Even friendship itself shou'd not win me to betray my trust.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Certainly never man was so unfortunate —Sure the fates have join'd in conspiracy to plague me in my amours—Nay, even the winds to com∣pleat my ruin have oppos'd my passage to England— A very fine comfort 'tis indeed—Here am I in con∣finement, without a friend to come to my assistance —What the devil shall I do in this exigence of fortune!

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P:
Ay, think Sir—we are in a fine place in∣deed —See what it is to be a great man! The governor provides you with lodgings here in the metropolitan castle, where, for the security of your person, he orders you a retinue of guards, as if in the king's palace; but methinks these honours, Sir, have a very scurvy countenance—Pray heaven
we an't exalted to the highest posts of the na∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I don't know what to think—The go∣vernor is certainly a man of quality, and can have no other view in this than the service of his country —All that makes me dubious is, whether I am a prisoner for my own sake, or the lady's.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: For both, Sir; but here comes one that will solve the riddle—A woman in a VEIL—There's certainly witchcraft in these women; for no sooner name a she-devil, but you find her at your elbow.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Cavalier! I come from a fair lady that was taken a prisoner with you this morning—Read that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: How does she bear her confinement?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Like a turtle moaning for its mate—The poor lady has fretted till she's in the spleen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I am sorry that I shou'd be the cause of her misfortunes—But vexations in love are like cloudy April showers; they bring forth the flowers of delight, to be chear'd by the warmth of the sun in its full lustre—But now for the letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P:
They say a witch commonly appears against ill weather, like a porpus before a storm—Now
prithee, damsel, what can we prognosticate from the sight of you?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Prithee, fellow, learn more manners, and to be less pert in your discourse.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nay, if you talk of being pert, commend me to a chambermaid, faith—But prithee, child, don't affect the airs of your mistress thus—I an't so damnably in love with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Hold your tongue, sirrah—My little emissary, tell the lady I'll wait on her at night according to her command—till when, farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Don't fail.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: You'll wait on her at night! Ha, ha, ha, Sir, 'tis already dark—therefore, if you have the keys of the castle in your pocket, let us shut the doors after us, and take up with another new lodg∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sirrah, I have a key, and a gold one too—Look here rascal—this, by the virtue of a glittering smile, can make the prison-doors fly open, and turn confinement into liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why, truly, it has an alluring look—but, methinks, a little aqua fortis now wou'd be of much more service.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Why, you blockhead, d'ye think I in∣tend to apply it to the bars, to break jail?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Ay, Sir, if you intend to keep your appoint∣ment with the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Yes, I do intend to keep it, and there∣fore this goes to the keeper.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So it may—But I believe he has more wit than to give you your freedom, if it does.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: You are mistaken, sirrah—What! Can it bribe a favourite to betray his prince, a senate their country, or a courtier his nearest friend—yet fail to tempt such fellows as jail-keepers to be per∣fidious to their trust?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: One question more, Sir—Have you quite forgot Fidelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: The absence of an old mistress makes room for a new one—Therefore I have blotted her from my fancy, like a painter that strikes one form out of his cloth, to lay in another.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, consider, and don't run headlong thus to your own destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Aspin turning philosopher!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Ay, Don Philip, my servant ape, a philosopher, like a cobbler that leaves his stall for a tub, and sets up for one of our reformed teachers.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P:
Perhaps he fancies himself inspir'd, and
thinks to deliver you by his inspiration to another place—I'm sure I'm sorry to see you where you are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Don Philip, you are happy in the af∣fections of a fair lady—Therefore, let not your con∣cern for me be an interruption in your pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My mistress and my friend share my heart—and I can never rejoice in one, when I am concern'd for the other—Is there any thing I can serve you in?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: There is—You know I told you this morning I had struck up a new amour—I can't tell you the lady's name, for she's a stranger to me— But had I my liberty, I might have the happiness of seeing her to-night.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Very well, Sir Charles—I find 'tis not in the power of fortune to reclaim you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, faith; I am resolv'd to overcome her ill-nature by laughing at it—And let what will happen, it shall never alter my humour, nor be an interruption to my pleasures.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Very finely resolv'd indeed—But suppose, Sir Charles. I shou'd gain you your freedom now, what security shall I have of your return?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: By the honour of an Englishman I'll return again.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I hope he'll have more wit than to keep his word though.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Enough—Here, who waits there?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: D'ye know this signet?

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: Yes, 'tis my lord governor's.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I command you, by virtue of this, to shew that gentleman the same respect as to myself— Give him his liberty—I'll answer it to the governor.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: I obey your orders.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Here, take this for your civility.

SP.SPEAKER: Keep.
SP.P: Sir, I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Now you have your liberty! You must take me along with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, I won't draw you into dangers— that wou'd be an ill return for so great an obli∣gation.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: That excuse won't serve—I am resolv'd to see this mistress of yours, Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Don't take it ill if I refuse you—For even Pylades and Orestes had their separate secrets —This lady is a woman of quality, and, shou'd I serve her so, she'll resent it.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: How can you be satisfied she's a woman of quality, if you never saw her face?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Her manners and appearance are a con∣vincing proof of that.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I thought, Sir Charles, you had known the ways of your own country better—Perhaps she may be a courtezan.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, no, I am convinc'd of the contrary —Those ladies are easily distinguish'd by their airs from women of quality—You may depend on it I am not so easily impos'd upon.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I won't press farther then against your inclinations—Good night; I'll see you again to∣morrow!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: So! Now fortune begins to turn her wheel—Some lucky spoke may rise quickly to my advantage—Aspin, lend me your pistol for my se∣curity.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Must I stay behind, Sir?—'Tis a servant's duty to follow his master's heels—Besides, I don't like this place for an amusement.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Come along then—It grows late, there∣fore I'll take a short turn, and wait for the happy signal.

DIV4.HEAD: SCENE, The governor's house.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The invention of a wit, the courage of a knight-errant, and the conduct of a politician, are all comprehended in an adventurous lover.—First we lay the scene of an assignation; then enter into the part, and if caught in the action, have a thou∣sand incidents to bring us off again.—I'm now assur'd, let what will interpose, love and resolution can never fail of success.
Is the coast clear?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Yes, Madam—The governor's gone to his repose.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Where Fidelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: In the same condition.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: And Don Philip?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: He's just come in, and retir'd to his apart∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Are all the family at rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: There's not one stirring in the house, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Then seek out for the cavalier. [Exit Flora. So! now I have nothing left me to fear, but a dis∣appointment from Sir Charles—Yet why that? We young girls can break the prison of a father's house to fly to our admirers, therefore such a gallant as he can never want a stratagem to release him∣self—besides, if Love's his guide, Fortune must be his assistant—but here they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Tread softly, Leonora's in the next room un∣dressing, and the governor lies near.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Thanks to my stars, that thro' the folds of darkness, I'm come, at length, to the regions of light.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I'll retire, that I may give you notice if any thing should happen.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Egad, this girl's worth gold—she knows civilly how to withdraw, and leave a pair of lovers together.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
You're a fine courtier truely, to let a lady, when she comes to see you, be carry'd away in captivity—I thought by this time to have heard
that you had broke your prison, slain your guards, and conquer'd whole armies to have gain'd my free∣dom—then you had been a lover indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Madam, I thought it wou'd be a much greater pleasure in a happy meeting to compleat my blessing, than to turn mad-man, and be run thro' for aiming at impossibilities.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: This is a satisfaction that every lover can give, because 'tis a pleasure to him—but your death wou'd have chronicled my fame in romance, to have been read by young virgins in after-ages, that such-a-one lov'd me so, he dy'd for the sake of me.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Look'e Madam, I am not so romantic as to die for the sake of being read in a novel, to divert girls in the green-sickness—My intention is to live for the end I was created, to propagate my generation—therefore, as I am a prisoner upon parole, and must return by break of day to the castle: let us reap the advantages of love, night, and opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
A fine speech indeed! you are like the athiest, all for pleasures at the present, and never have a thought of futurity—I expected you wou'd have prov'd a Paris, at least—that is, have prof∣fered
to have carry'd me to a safe harbour, and there to have given yourself up for life, as a personal security for your love.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: For life—too much resembles marriage, which is the disagreeable part of love—besides, my honour's engag'd for my return.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Love is the nicest point of honour—there∣fore the engagement is of greater force—but I know the reason why you are thus reserv'd—you have a pre-engagement on your heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis true, I have lov'd another; but one love, like one power, yields to a superior.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Very well, Sir Charles, I see you are too inconstant to be trusted—for now, by your own confession, shou'd you see another, I must yield your heart to her beauty, because you may chance to think it superior to mine

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Madam, that's impossible—for the charms of your wit so conspire with those of your beauty, that they must fix ev'n inconstancy itself.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I esteem such flights but as compliments, Sir Charles—and a compliment to a lady, like a poetical flattering panegyric, is the severest satire—for it shows the persons what they ought to be in the reverse of what they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: What arguments can I then use to con∣vince you of my affections?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: None. I shou'd as soon take an atheist for a man of sense; a wit for a politician; or a politi∣cian for a man of honour; as a libertine, like Sir Charles, for a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: But, Madam, can you have so mean an opinion of your own desert, as to believe a heart that has been your captive, can ever break your chains?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No! but you have been false already, and inconstancy is as bad a proof of love, as seurrility is of wit—the one proceeds from a false genius, and the other from a degenerate passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Come, this is trifling away the happy minutes. [A pislol fir'd.] Ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What means that noise!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This is certainly my dog of a servant!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Haste, or you'll be discover'd; the gover∣nor's rising!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Where shall hide myself!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Alas! here's no conveniency—therefore, fly quickly!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: If he goes out at the door, the governor meets him!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: What shall I do then!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Jacomo, Pedro, lights there!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: They're coming here!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Then there's no time to trifle!—Out, out of window, Sir, quickly!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Out of the window! so, shall I break my neck, to preserve a lady's reputation.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Lights, lights there, quickly!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: For heav'n's sake Sir Charles, fly! for my honour, and your life!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Fly! 'Sdeath, Madam, what do you mean? D'ye think I have wings like a Cupid to fly out of the window!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Your stay will ruin me, Sir Charles!—be∣sides, you may safely get by a balcony, from my closet into the court-yard!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This comes now of making ill use of of one's time, Well, I must run the risque; but a pox on me, if ever I draw myself into these scrapes again.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: What course shall we take now?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Haste to my daughter's chamber there.
Some of you follow me, to search the court-yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Hrk! there are some of them coming here!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Nay, then, out go the lights—Now, per∣haps, they'll conclude we are at rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I shiver with apprehensions—My father will certainly find Sir Charles or his man in the court∣yard!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: That we must leave to fortune, Madam— In the mean time, let us retire softly, for fear we are discover'd.

DIV4.STAGE: Enter Sir Charles feeling his way.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Vexations are always the fruits of an intrigue—What shall I do? Where's my rascally servant? The house is alarm'd, and I am in the dark within the verge of the governor's palace!

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I have rais'd the house with the report of my pistol, and now security's the word—Odd, 'tis very dark—Every step I have taken, I have knock'd my head against some post or wall, till I have almost beat out my brains.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: If I am not mistaken, I hear the tread of a man.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I warrant you now, my master is so full of his sport with the lady, that he hears nothing of this disturbance—Odd, I can but laugh to think how he 'll look when he is catch'd in the nick of his performance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: There's certainly somebody in this yard— If I don't take care, I may chance to lose my life before I know where I am—therefore, old friend, stand to my assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Hark, I hear somebody—they steal softly, thinking to catch me here before I am aware of 'em—These Spaniards are damn'd fellows—they love to run a man thro' in the dark—Odd, I'll up with my heels, and trust fear to be my guide—O lud, I am caught! Help! help!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Whoever you are, if you offer to stir an inch, you 're a dead man.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Oh lud, Sir, save my life, and I'll peach— I'll tell you the whole plot.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Oh! Is it your worship, Sir?—This is all owing to you, you rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Have you search'd every place carefully? Follow me, some of you, to the court-yard.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
Egad the enemy will be at our heels presently—Sirrah, march after me by the sound
of my tread—Ha! What have I stumbled against? A chair! It seems set in my way by fortune— Lights are coming—I'll in here, and hide myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, let me come in too, for if I am taken, I shall either be hang'd like a dog, or knock'd o'the head like an ox.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sirrah, here's no room—therefore shift for yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: They 're all coming; for heaven's sake, let me sit upon your knee, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Get out you rascal, I shall be discover'd by your folly.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: This is very barbarous—I wish I cou'd find out a horse-pond—I'd run up to my neck to secure myself—Here they come—If I am caught, I'll be reveng'd and peach, I'm resolv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Have you been at Leonora's chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st. Serv.
SP.P: Yes, my Lord—and I believe she's in her bed, for I saw no light.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I thought I heard somebody leap out of her window—Secure the gates.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Don Philip! Have you caught the alarm too?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My Lord, I heard a noise in my room, and came to see what's the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: We thought somebody had broke in—but we can find no one but our own family.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Have you made a diligent search, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: We have search'd almost every where—ex∣cept any one's hid in that chair.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Give me the light, I'll see—

DIV4.STAGE: [Opens the chair, Sir Cha. nods at him to take no notice.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Is there any one?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: No, my Lord—Death and confusion! Sir Charles there!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: 'Twas a mistake betwixt sleep and waking— I'll retire to rest again—A good repose to you Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P:
The like to your Lordship.— So, they are all retir'd now, to their respective chambers—My Lord, would have persuaded me this was an illusion—So he thinks to deceive me, whilst I deceive him—We wou'd both hide the
disgrace from each other.—Hist, Sir Charles you may come forth now.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Dear Philip thou art the best of friends.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Am I not? to be made a property to my own shame: Is this generous usage?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: What mean you?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: You have supplanted me in Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: 'Tis a mistake—I came to a young Lady that's a prisoner—who was taken with me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: That's a poor evasion, and below a man of honour—I know the reason now, why you refus'd to admit of my company—besides, there's no such person in the house—Look'e, Sir Charles, I shall expect satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Look'e, you are mad—for jealousy is no other than madness—I tell you there is such a lady; perhaps, you may be so blinded with love, that you may not regard any body in the family but the governor and his daughter—but if what I say is not true, to-morrow you shall have what satis∣faction you require.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Till then farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
Farewel, till you come to your senses again—So! I have brought myself to a fine pass indeed—I have kill'd one hot-brain'd fool for his jealousy, and now to compleat my misfortune, he
too has catch'd the infection—What shall I do? If I stay here and trust the inquisition, 'tis ten times more unmerciful than a Middlesex jury—A man can never have fair play for his life—to touch cold iron, and come off like a gentleman—Shall I then lay hold on this opportunity, and make my escape! No! They shall never say an Englishman's so base a coward.

Q.L: Let the hot Spaniard boast his virtue here,
And honour's loss in jealous notions fear.
A Briton scorns to prove his country's shame,
And rather hazards life, than taints his same.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: COME, come Madam, I'm not to be so impos'd upon! you may deny it as long as you please, but you can't persuade me out of my senses —Did not I, last night, actually see Sir Charles hid under your window in the court-yard?—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Suppose you did, Sir?—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Then, Madam, I can suppose it to be no advantage to your character—S'death, am I to be made a property! a mere pander! to carry on an intrigue against my own honour?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Very well! go on, Sir, go on.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: So I can, Madam. Is it prudent for a young lady, just upon her marriage, to entertain a cavalier alone at midnight—nay, in her own chamber too! unknown to her father, or any one that shou'd be the guardian of her honour?—Such conduct is mighty reputable indeed, Madam!—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Suppose such a person was here, Sir—is there no other place that cou'd entertain him but my apartment?—Am I the only person he cou'd come to?—Must I be accountable for his being here?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: No, Madam, by no means—'Tis pro∣bable to believe a person of his quality, might have an affair with one of your servants only—S'death, d'ye take me for a fool! is there any other young lady in the house? Look'e, Madam, I shou'd not so tamely take this of Sir Charles, but that I scorn to insult a man in his misfortunes—however, I can be yet capable of resentment—for know, I'll im∣mediately demand my contract of your father, and return back to Madrid.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: If I let him go, this may give room for suspi∣cion, and suspicion will bring a discovery. [Aside. Hold, Sir—Not that 'tis worth my while to clear my innocence, for your sake, but for my father's: Know then, here is another young lady in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Aye! who? tell me that pray, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The prisoner, Sir—I shall have a fine time to satisfy your scruples.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: The prisoner! ha, ha, ha! you are both in the same story, I find—your scheme is ex∣cellently well laid—Were I a zealous dotard, or a British husband, perhaps I might be credulous enough to believe any thing—but this deceit won't take; it won't, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: How! what indecency have I been guilty of to merit this usage?—but know, since you are still resolv'd to traduce my honour, there are those, Sir, that will vindicate it—This is not to be borne with patience!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nay, Madam, don't disorder yourself thus—for you may henceforth meet Sir Charles as often as you please—and expose your reputa∣tion as much as you think fit; it shall never give me any further uneasiness I can assure you, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Insolent! before you had resolv'd to treat me after this manner, you might, at least, have ask'd my father if there was no such person in the house!—Is this the return for all his friend∣ship? But here comes the lady herself, I shall leave her to give you satisfaction.—Provoking man!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Ha! what do I see? Here comes a young lady indeed! I'm afraid jealousy has carry'd me too far—Soft! I'll lay aside this heat a little, if possible.— Enter Fidelia. But still methinks my choler rises so, I know not how to suppress it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Here we may learn their discourse. Me∣thinks, tho' I am partly in fault, I am exaspe∣rated at such treatment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Ha! who's here? What can be the mean∣ing of this!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nay, Madam, don't start—I hope the sight of me has not put you in a consternation.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Sir, I came to meet a friend, and being lost in thought, pardon me, if I was a little sur∣priz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, whoever you came to meet, and however strange it may seem to you, you are the only person I cou'd wish for at present.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Me, Sir! I don't know that ever I saw you in my life before!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Very like so, Madam—But however you may be surpriz'd, you have been the cause that has rais'd this disorder in my soul, and 'tis in your power alone to appease it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I the cause of your disorder, Sir!—certainly the man's mad!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Pardon me, if my temper's a little ruffled.—Perhaps I may be impertinent—but if you have the least compassion, I beg you answer me to one particular.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: With all my heart, Sir, if it lies in my power.—What can the man mean! He looks as if he was distracted!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Answer me directly and sincerely, Madam —for my scruples are as of great a consequence, as those of troubled minds, that apply to casuists for ease.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Sir, you surprise me wonderfully—What satisfaction can I, that am a stranger, give you?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: The greatest! and only in one trivial answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: What is it, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: D'ye know such a person as Sir Charles Winlove, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How, Sir! your question startles me, in∣deed.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: It need not; for, as I am a cavalier, I ask you for no treacherous design—therefore be kind, and case me with an answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How earnest and concern'd he seems! Sure he has no design to offer love—Perhaps he may come as a spy to betray me—I know not what to think.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I conjure you by all the soft∣ness of your sex, to free me from my doubts— for the whole quiet of my soul depends on what you say.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I will—whate'er the consequence may prove, I leave to you—Know then, I scorn on any terms to deny my affection for Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: This satisfaction cheers me indeed!— Curse on my jealous folly!—Are you a native of Valencia, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P:
No, Sir, I am totally a stranger to it— Love, that has been my guide to ruin, was my directer hither.—But now, Sir, answer me a question
in my turn.—Are you acquainted with Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Nay, if they come to particulars, we are lost again.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I know him well—He is my dearest friend.—How have I wrong'd him with suspicions!

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Your friend, say you! Can you give me any tidings of him, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I question not, but he is return'd in safety to the castle—I am now immediately going to him about some affairs of consequence; in the mean time depend on my interest to serve you both.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: In the castle! said he so, or did I dream? Oh! for the wings of Love to haste and be con∣vinc'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So, here's another hare started—Where are you going in such haste, Fidelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, I hear that the cavalier, that I'm in search of, is a prisoner in the castle; therefore, I must immediately fetch my VEIL, and hasten to see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now am I more unfortunate than ever!—What stop shall I put to this?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P:
Madam, you must again consult your wit: you see discoveries gather like clouds, and I'm
afraid the main storm will come rattling upon us immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I was never so provok'd in my life, as I was at Don Philip's jealousies, and all this I undergo for a person that I'm not secure of—For as Fide∣lia was the first object of Sir Charles's affections, she'll still be the mistress of his heart—and pos∣session there, as in the law, will make her eleven points before me.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Then, Madam, in my humble opinion, 'twill be better to drop this amour—This lady will, in the end, discover all—therefore, I think it better to forsake a victory than to lose it.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I am of the same opinion—But what shall I do in this affair?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: E'en follow the example of declining cour∣tiers—that is, whilst you've possession of his affec∣tions, think 'tis more honour to resign than to be remov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: But I mean, now I have gone so far, how shall I retire without hazarding my reputation?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Shou'd you trust his love, even the success of your amour will be of ill consequence—Therefore, appoint another assignation with him—let her into the secret, so far as not to give her uneasiness, and carry her with you to meet him.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Prudently advis'd—But see, she comes: I must not let her go, for that will ruin all.
Are you resolv'd upon this adventure, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Yes: now I know where Sir Charles is, methinks, I am all impatience to see him!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I'd advise you to apply yourself to second thoughts, and ere you fix upon a resolution, to weigh well the consequence of this proceeding.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: The consequence!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Aye: consider, you are no more mistress of your liberty—but are here now in confinement.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: In confinement, Madam! I desire you to explain your meaning?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Then, in short, to clear up the mystery at once; my father is an intimate friend of yours—and for the sake of that friendship, he has here en∣gag'd to secure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Am I so barbarously betray'd then! I thought, Madam, I had come to the governor's daughter for refuge, and not to a prison to be con∣fin'd in.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P:
I can't but make an allowance to your sur∣prize—and, therefore, yield to your resentment.
But I could wish, you wou'd make yourself a little easy—for, perhaps, I might yet propose a method for your satisfaction.—Ha! my father! for hea∣ven's sake calm yourself a little.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What makes the lady appear in such a dis∣order, Leonora?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Now the cloud is gather'd, it begins to break before we are prepar'd for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: A trifle only, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: No, Madam, 'tis no trifle—My lord, I think I have reason to be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How, Madam!—I hope you have receiv'd no ill-treatment from any of my family.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The lady was going abroad without your leave, and I believe she may take it ill, because I told her the consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How, Madam! I am sorry you shou'd be led into such an error.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My lord, I confess a point of ceremony might have oblig'd me to ask'd your leave—but either there is a mistake on your side: or if you rightly knew me, and the cause why I am here, I believe you wou'd not refuse me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: 'Tis because I know both, Madam, I do re∣fuse you—and tho' you may command what free∣dom you please in the house, I beg you still to re∣member you're a prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: A prisoner! Upon what account? By what authority, my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Madam, my authority was never wont to be call'd in question—besides, I thought I had satisfy'd you as to that, when I seiz'd you yesterday with Sir Charles Winlove.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Seiz'd me yesterday with Sir Charles Win∣love! What does your lordship mean?—In short, I believe you're impos'd upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Madam, if my senses are right, I am cer∣tain I am not impos'd upon—and you must pardon me, if I can't consent to be so—Did not I bring you yesterday here in custody?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: No, my lord: this lady and her servant, can witness I came here alone, and on my own accord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: To contradict the fair, may seem a breach of respect due to the sex—therefore, I can make you no other answer than this, that when young ladies are in love, 'tis no wonder if they are thus forgetful.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, I desire that you'll speak, and satisfy my lord as to your knowledge in this affair.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Madam, you see my lord is already satis∣fy'd —Besides, since you are wound in the toil, I shan't draw myself into the snare to deliver you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My lord, this is very hard, thus to be shut out of the light of reason, to remain in the dark∣ness of mystery.

SP.SPEAKER: Ser.
SP.P: Come along there—bring him before my lord governor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ha! what new disturbance is this?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Gentlemen, dear gentlemen, don't collar me so furiously—consider, to choke a man with∣out a halter is against law—besides, I am no Turk, and therefore am not ambitious of the honour of being strangled like a Grand Vizier.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! 'tis Sir Charles's man—perhaps this may be of an ill consequence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Let go your hold of him. What's the mean∣ing of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Serv.
SP.P: My lord, this is the fellow that made the disturbance last night—for, searching him, we found this pistol conceal'd in one of his pockets.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Serv.
SP.P: My lord, we believe he came upon a very traiterous design—for we discover'd him hid under one of the maids beds.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: A very pretty fellow indeed!—Take him away, I'll consider of a punishment for the rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: This is an admirable place for law and discipline—Priests enjoin penance for lenten mor∣tification, and judges hang folks without hearing their defence.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: D'ye you presume to murmer in my pre∣sence, sirrah? What have you to say for your∣self?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Say! why nothing, my lord! I am unpro∣vided with counsel, and therefore, my motion is, that I may defer my trial.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Prithee, fellow, answer me to the pur∣pose —What are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Not guilty, my lord; not guilty.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I mean, sirrah, who are you? What's your business here?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: My lord, as to who I am, I am my master's servant; and as to my business here, if you don't like my company, I am ready to take my leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Stop him:—I never saw so impudent a fel∣low before.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: They say, Madam, he's an Englishman's servant; but I'm sure he has an Irish assurance.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Pray heav'n he has assurance enough to bring himself off; for I'm afraid this will open the scene, and immediately discover all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Hark'e fellow—give some account of your∣self; what profession are you of?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why, my lord, I wait upon my master— In his chamber I'm his valet in ordinary; sometimes his pimp in extraordinary; and commonly, have the honour to be of his cabinet council.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Thou art an excellent rascal, indeed!— Prithee, fellow, who is your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So! these great folks are as forgetful of every thing, as they are of their promises—Is then my face a stranger to your lordship?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sirrah, if you had gold enough in your pocket to answer the brass of your countenance, you might outvie the most impudent courtier in Europe—but don't presume to trifle with me thus any longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Then to refresh your memory, my lord, I am Sir Charles Winlove's servant, and your lord∣ship's prisoner at discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ha! I had forgot the rogue, indeed!—So, Madam, does the scene now begin to open or not?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My lord, I am innocent of the charge; and therefore, am satisfy'd this can have no relation to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: 'Tis well, Madam; this will appear imme∣diately.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I'm afraid, Flora, now come the clue that will unravel the mystery at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: In the first place, rascal, what provok'd you to make such a disturbance?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why, my lord, I was assaulted in your lord∣ship's court-yard by a great mastiff, and I used that pistol as an instrument to allay hi fury.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: In the mean time, where was your master?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Only playing a game or two, with my lady, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Very well, Madam!—Go on, sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Nay, my lord, I know no more, than that he was carried away from me by a she-confident of the lady's, vulgarly call'd a chamber-maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Here's a treacherous rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How! Flora—did you conduct him to the lady's chamber?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I, my lord!—Certainly the fellow has not the impudence to say so!

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P:
Nay, I had not such cat's eyes to know any one in the dark; but methinks your voice agrees
much with that pert lady's that brought the letter to my master.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So, this rascal will betray all!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Then this was a concerted business, I find. —Sirrah, let me hear no more of these practices.— Discharge the fellow, and let him return to his master.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So, they say, confess and be hang'd!—But I am come as clear off by turning evidence, as if I had bought off the verdict of a jury.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: So, Madam, I hope now you'll no longer deny your correspondence with Sir Charles Win∣love —But I am sorry, for the sake of my respect to your father, to see you still so regardless of your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My lord, believe me, I am innocent— and if Sir Charles has had any affair here—'tis with some of your own family.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I cou'd almost wish to be ignorant of such convincing proofs in relation to this affair—but you must pardon me, if I grow now to be more cautious of your proceedings—Flora, shou'd I find you in the least concern'd in this, you shall no longer re∣main in my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now is my time!
—Methinks your countenance, Madam, speaks a surprize at these proceedings.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I own I am so confus'd, that I scarce know whether this is reality, or an illusion.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I see, Fidelia, you are a little acquainted with the artifices of love, tho' you are caught in the snare—Can't you dive into the mystery of this?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: An ignorant innocence is peculiar to our sex; and to dive into mystery, they say, is a sin in any one but a brother of the profession—therefore, I shall let it rest, till it unravels itself.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Were I in your case, I should rather be fired with a woman's curiosity, than be so unmov'd at the turns of my fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
Leo.
SP.P: Alas, Fidelia! I am in as great a concern as you are—for my quiet is equally at stake with yours—but if you will consent to come into my measures, there is yet a way to make us both easy.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Propose it: for methinks I cou'd embrace any method that cou'd bring me to the sight of Sir Charles.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Know then, my father has contracted me to one, who has all the qualities that can make him agreeable—notwithstanding which, I have lately entertain'd the addresses of an English cavalier, who now proves to be the very same you were speaking of.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: What! Sir Charles Winlove, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The same.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How! after having ruin'd me, can he be so perfidious to make his addresses to another!—False man!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Alas, all men are the same, Fidelia!—In short, they use us as children do their toys; are fond of us at first—but quickly neglect us to fol∣low new fancies.—But to proceed—Yesterday, I met this Sir Charles at his lodgings, where my father came, attended with officers, and seiz'd us to∣gether! —He was carry'd to the castle, and I was brought home conceal'd in a VEIL; where, by the circumstances of the story, I find he mistook me for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Wou'd you be willing, Madam, to resign your interest in Sir Charles, provided I would stand to the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Yes, Fidelia, you shall now see me throw off the softness of a lover for the craft of a poli∣tician, to serve you—And a a first proof of my friendship, I'll write to him as from myself: Flora shall carry the letter; and if he can get his liberty, I'll engage he shall meet us in two hours at ano∣ther place.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: This is as I cou'd with, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: One thing more.—I overheard your dis∣course with that cavalier who is to be my husband— I see his jealousies are cur'd, and all points are now clear'd to my content.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Let us then be quick in our proceedings.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: With all my heart—we'll now retire, and I'll write immediately to Sir Charles.—Flora, be ready within call to attend us.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: So, my lady is now come off again to her satisfaction.—If our sex were as prudent in resolution, as they are quick at invention, they would not prove such weak fools to the men.— However, I have learnt now, if occasion serves, to carry on an intrigue of my own—for I find, tho' dangers happen from love, wit never fails to turn the tables upon fortune.

Q.L: Thus, when from fate our disappointments fall,

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: MY old friend, once more I congratulate your arrival to Valencia—You are come in good time to vindicate the honour of your family.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Come in a good time, say you! No, I am come in a very ill time, I can't so much as thank you for your civility.—Hark'e, prithee look in my face now—Am not I very much alter'd? Have not I something very rueful in my counte∣nance?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What makes you fancy so?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Because, methinks, I am no better than a raven, I can croak nothing but bad news.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come, come, be cheerful; all will go well again.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Yes, truly! all is like to go mighty well, indeed!—My son-in-law, that was to be, has been desperately wounded; my daughter's run away, and my family's disgraced for ever; and you expect me to be cheerful, do you!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, but hear reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Nay, but I won't hear reason! What have I to do with reason, when I come in search of revenge?—You say, you have 'em both in your custody!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Suppose I have! You tell me the wounded cavalier is recovered, then what pretence can I have for detaining Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: No matter—I 'll conceal his recovery, and have the dog suffer for his death.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Fye! I am asham'd to see your passion so overcome your reason—Suppose your daughter loves him?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Loves him! 'Sdeath, who doubts but she does love him!—What, because the silly baggage has been so weak as to suffer him to ruin her, you would have me play the old dotard, and be as great a fool as my daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Still you mistake me.—Why will you en∣deavour thus to widen the breach, when I wou'd bring matters to a reconciliation?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: To a reconciliation!—Ha, ha, ha! this is pleasant, indeed!—The son of a whore has stole away my daughter, and for ought I know, she may have her belly up to her mouth; and you talk of bringing matters to a reconciliation!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: But suppose she shou'd love him; and he shou'd have an equal passion for her?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Why then, my curse be an equal portion for them both!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Perhaps, he wou'd consent to marry her.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Marry her! no, no, no! The young fe∣llows of this age, are not such fools as to debauch women, and afterwards to marry 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, but—

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Nay, but I know what it is to be a young fellow! I tell you their vows always dissolve with virginities, and when the fort's surrender'd, all for∣mer promises are void o' course.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: There are, indeed, too many of the fair sex in that unhappy condition; but why shou'd you judge so hardly of your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Why shou'd I not judge for Did she not run away with him? Has she not a anguine com∣plexion, and he a brawny back? Is she not a pro∣mising girl, and he a sprightly young fellow?— Then, why may not my daughter happen to be with child?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Still you perplex yourself with fancied in∣juries only—Was she ever loose in her behaviour?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: No, I always believ'd her to be a very modest girl: But now, she has certainly tasted of the tree of knowledge—he has open'd her senses, and enter'd her into her rudiments.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Did you ever love your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Yes, too well; tho' indeed, she was a very good girl, and deserv'd it—Nay, now I think of her, the tears of affection still come into my eyes!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Indulge that tenderness, and reason will come o' course—D'ye think I am your friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: How shou'd I know that? We were friends once, indeed!—That is, when we were young— Then we us'd to drink our bottle together, ruin'd as many girls, and made as many cuckolds as any rake-hells in Europe—But now, the scene i chang'd: you are my lord governor! time, ab∣sence, and state-affairs may have drove me out of your memory.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come, you shall see I am still your friend: have patience, and I'll endeavour to bring all to a right understanding.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Patience!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, nay, suppress your choler, 'till you see whether you have reason for it—I'll now imme∣diately go, and propose an honourable treaty to Sir Charles: in the mean time I beg you to retie, and not see your daughter 'till I return to tell you my success.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P:
Your return will bring me a fine account of success, indeed!—We men are certainly most
unhappy wretches—When we are young, we get children in the heat of our blood, who, when we come to be old, grow disobedient, and break our hearts in order to get into our estates—Well, I'll say no more, but I'll send this rebel daughter of mine to a nunnery, and there she shall mortify for the sins of the flesh—but for that rogue that has debauch'd her, if ever I see him again, I'll have his blood, tho' I meet him in a sanctuary.

DIV4.HEAD: SCENE, The castle.
DIV4.STAGE: Enter Sir Charles Winlove and Don Philip.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Sir Charles, I am now convinc'd of your innocence—My suspicions were the fond er∣rors of my love, and as such I hope you 'll esteem 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I do; when I consider that jealous eyes always see thro' a microscope, that magnifies the meanest trisles, to seem as of the greatest conse∣quence —but had you not been my friend, I shou'd not so tamely have submitted to such usage.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P:
I own the rashness of my folly to be great—Let fools have the obstinacy to perfist in their errors—a generous soul esteems it rather as a point of honour, when convine'd, to acknowledge
'em.—Therefore, now let us turn the discourse— I'll assure you, Sir Charles, I think the captive is very beautiful.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Beautiful as ever I saw!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: But still, methinks, my lady excels her.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Every lover is apt to think his own mistress the most deserving—Mine has wit as well as beauty; and where the lusciousness of one may cloy the appetite, the other whets it again, and makes all her charms as agreeable as ever.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Wit and beauty are two irresistible wea∣pons, indeed; but, I find, you are in a fair way to succeed in your hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, faith—Notwithstanding she has so many perfections, my success was but very in∣different: whether the inconstant star that governs the sex rul'd, I know not; but my reception prov'd as great a disappointment, as the accident after∣wards did a surprize.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Oh, that was a meer feint, only to make a trial of your love! I find you are not rightly ac∣quainted with the variety of a lady's humour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, nor ever shall, if 'tis so much ad∣dicted to whimsey.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: But a lover shou'd make it his business, first, to study the temper of his mistress, and then to study every method that may promote her pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Then I am not so much a lover as to submit my reason to frenzy—For to study the tem∣per of a woman, is like searching out for the phi∣losopher's stone—a man may spend his estate, run mad, and grow never the wiser.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Notwithstanding your harsh censure of the sex, I wish I knew the humour of my lady, so far as to gain remission for my solly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: So, this is ever the consequence of jea∣lousy —First, you quarrel with your mistress for no reason, and then are never easy till you're re∣concil'd.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: I own it is a weakness, indeed; but a Spaniard is so unfortunate in his passions, that he can no more avoid the rashness of jealousy, than he can expel the heat of his climate.—But what service, Sir Charles, can I do you now in your amour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Why then, once more to trust you as a friend, I have this day receiv'd a letter from the lady:—but sure there are such beauties in the style! not Ovid is more soft, nor Horace more sairical.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: What are the contents of it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
'Tis a kind invitation to another ap∣pointment; but nterspers'd with reflections from an excellent talent of wit in relation to my servant's
carelessness:—Here, prithee read it, and give me your opinion.

DIV4.P: So! Where have you been, sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Sir, I have run thro' as dangerous adven∣tures as a knight-errant—but as I was predestinated to act the part of champion, I was prepar'd with armour accordingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Were you so? Prithee, let's hear the wonderful description of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why, Sir, courage was the support of my back; caution the defence of my breast; wit was my noble head-piece; and this pistol, the weapon with which I encounter'd death and destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: That pistol, sirrah! What occasion had you last night to make it give such an alarm?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Why, Sir, I was assaulted by no less than a fiery dragon—In short, a great mastiff flew at my throat, and had I not had the courage to have encounter'd his fury, I had certainly been torn in pieces.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nay then, Sir Charles, you must never be angry with him for his valour—Aspin has now rival'd the fame of St. George—and I think his statue ought to be set up in memory of this atchieve∣ment, as a second honour to your country.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: What is past, was but a trial for the courage of a hero—But the next misfortune I fell into, re∣quir'd the deepest policy of a statesman.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Aye! prithee what was that?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: I was this morning discover'd by some of the servants, and carry'd, vi & armis, a prisoner before my lord governour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Aye! How came you off there, Aspin?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, I brought myself off with a wet finger!—First, the governour ask'd me several questions—I generously told him the affair you had last night with the lady—confession merited mercy, and I was immediately discharg'd like a man of honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Were you so, sirrah? Know then, ras∣cal, you have discover'd all my designs, and I'll this moment make an example of you—

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Hold, Sir Charles—consider, his folly is below your resentment.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I have scarce patience to suffer the dog in my sight—Rascal! deceitful villain!

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Is this the return for all the dangers I have suffer'd—Well, 'tis an ungrateful age—but I am not the first man of merit that has been slighted after his faithful service.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Come, be pacify'd Sir Charles—all may be easily brought off again.—Here, take your letter: I have read it, and approve of the de∣sign. —But have you prepar'd any place for your appointment with the lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No, as to that part, I believe, I must rely upon you.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Then I can help you at a dead lift— My apartment has a door into another street— Order her to be carry'd the back-way, and as she's a stranger to the place, she may be easily de∣ceiv'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I like the proposal well.—Aspin, go you this moment and conduct 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So, tho' we men of merit are so barba∣rously us'd, we are always wanted in a case of necessity.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Sirrah, no prating; mind what I say, and go out of my sight. [Exit Aspin.] Now which way shall I obtain my liberty for this adven∣ture?

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Oh, I'll gain you that freedom—and that you may the better by day-light pass unknown, I'll send you my cloak, and you shall muffle yourself in that—Ha! the governour! What means this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Don Philip, I see your friendship is not like that of the world, a meer counterfeit profession— for you endeavour to serve the person you value, tho' you see him loaded with affliction.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My lord, friendship is only shew'd in adversity: a man in prosperity has abundance of professors—but had he need of one, not a friend amongst 'em all.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Your friendship is mutual—Sir Charles sav'd your life, and you 'd now return it with the preservation of his—so that you both are exceptions from the general rule of the world; for there's scarce a person in it, besides yourselves, can say, I have a friend.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Because the reverse of friendship is the product of a degenerate age; where honesty passes for folly; perfidiousness for good policy; and all manner of knavery, for necessary wisdom to thrive in the world.—So that a man can no more be assur'd of friends in adversity, than a king or coun∣try in distress—when those that shou'd be so, en∣rich themselves in their destruction.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
You are a young Stoic indeed, Sir Charles— However, I come now to stand your friend, for
want of pity, in your case, wou'd be downright cruelty—and therefore, give me leave to make some proposals that may be to your satisfaction— Don Philip, I hope you'll excuse me a little.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: My lord, I take my leave—Hark'e, Sir Charles, what shall I do in this affair?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Go, and detain the lady till I come— and d'ye hear, leave orders with the keeper for my freedom.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Never fear—I'll manage all to the best advantage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I have this morning receiv'd advice of the cavalier's recovery, that was thought to have been kill'd—This I must yet keep as a secret, till I have brought matters to bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Now, my lord, if you please, I am ready to receive your proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sir Charles, I am come to you concerning an affair of consequence.—You must know, Alon∣zo, the father of Fidelia, and I, when young, were never separated from each other—Now, I understand by a letter from Madrid, you have late∣ly depriv'd him of his daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: How! depriv'd him of her, my lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P:
Aye; but methinks I would willingly heal this breach—therefore I'd advise you to find some
means, by which you might reconcile yourself to him, and restore the honour of the young lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My lord, I understand you not—'Tis true, I love Fidelia as my life; but for her honour, it is not in the least forfeited on my account.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Her father is of a quite contrary opinion.— Therefore, if you have either a value for yourself, or an affection for the young lady, you will consent to those means, that will contribute to her ease, as well as to your own security.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My lord, I own the wildness of my youth.—But I have so true an affection for Fidelia, that for my security, I prize it not in comparison with her content.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: I see, Sir Charles, you begin to guess at my meaning—Therefore I question not but to find you the man of honour, I was apt at first sight to believe you—Her same upon your account is very much become the discourse of the world— therefore to reconcile all, wou'd you be willing to accept her for a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My lord, I needed not this preparation to embrace such welcome proposals.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Consent to that, and I'll engage your par∣don shall be secur'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
My life is of as little value to me now, as when I ran the risque of forfeiting it for her—
But for the looser wishes that my inconstancy has been guilty of, cou'd I be so happy to see her, they wou'd immediately vanish at her sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Know then, Sir Charles, the lady is still in Valencia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: How! in Valencia, my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: She has remain'd in confinement at my house, ever since I yesterday seiz'd her at your lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Nay, then there is a mistake in this— The lady that was taken with me, I can assure you, is not Fidelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Her father's servant cou'd not be mistaken, and he afterwards saw her at my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I know her face too well to be deceiv'd— The lady that was taken with me, I was a stranger to.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: This is a pretty contrivance indeed!— In the first place, the young lady owns herself to be Fidelia, but at the same time denies a corres∣pondence with you—and now you own a corres∣pondence with her, but deny she is the person— Who was it then that you had an assignation with last night at my house?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Since you have made a discovery in that affair, 'twa with the lady that was seiz'd with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: And that lady, you positively say, is not Fidelia?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: I do, my lord, and if I am in my senses, I am sure I can affirm it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now she actually says she is—but denies that she has either seen you, or had any discourse with you in Valencia.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Nay, then, there is a farther mystery in this!—I am certain, the lady I met last night was not Fidelia.—Now if the person you mean, that denies all this, shou'd prove to be her, then your lordship is mistaken, for she can't be the same that was seiz'd with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, there has been no art magic to trans∣form her, nor to change one person to another.— Therefore depend on't, she's the same—Now the messenger from her father went away satisfy'd she was the right; and she, upon examination, own'd herself to be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This makes it all seem more intricate still.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come with me, and let your sight convince you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: By this he'll discover the lady is gone abroad, in order to meet me▪—What can I do? I must submit.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Come along then, Sir Charles—methinks I am impatient to have this riddle explain'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: And I the like, my lord—for I am sure, as the story lies now, there is so great a my∣stery in it, 'tis beyond the power of a churchman to unfold it, till we see farther.

DIV4.HEAD: SCENE, Don Philip's apartment in the governor's house.
DIV4.STAGE: Enter Aspin, Fidelia, and Leonora VIL'D.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: So, this is the first time that ever I turn'd gentleman-usher—Methinks I make a notable figure in my preferment—Nay, I don't know, but I may rise to be a great man.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: The creature look, as if he was in love with himself—Hark'e, fellow, where have you brought us?

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Not a jo from your own inclination, I sup∣pose —Look'e, Madam, it is master', business to answer your questions—Here my service is at end— Methinks, I begin to have a jantee air already— I'll see how I can compliment [Asid.].—Ladies, I am your most humble servant, and so I take my leave of such illustrious beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: I never saw such a in my life!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now we may venture to UNVEIL—for I know not where we are, by reason I never lookd of the chair.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Perhaps Sir Charles may have provided us one of his mistres's aparments—for I know not what to think of him, now he's grown to in∣constant.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Sure I'm no stranger to this place, idelia.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: They seem to be handsome lodgings, and methinks are very prettily urnish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! I am surpriz'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: At what, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: As I live, we are betray'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: How! heaven forbid!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: We are in my father's house, and this is Don Philip's apartment!

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: If so, here's treachery indeed! What shall we do?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
Fide.
SP.P: Then, Madam, our resolution must be quick as our thought; for they'll certainly be here presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh, for a stratagem now to outwit 'em!— Stay, I'll look thro' the key-hole, and see i I can discern my servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Is there any body to be seen?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Yes, there's Flora working with her needle at the window.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Call softly, Madam; perhaps she may hear you.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Flora, hist, Flora!—Don't you hear?

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Who calls?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: 'Tis I—Fetch the key that belongs to the door, and open it.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: It lies, Madam, on your father's table— I'll run and fetch it immediately.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Now we shall succeed, and every thing will be right again.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Madam, 'tis all too late—somebody's coming up.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Ha! 'Tis Don Philip! Assist me wit now, or never—Keep close your VEIL, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: What do I see, Leonora here!

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Seeing this lady in your apartment, Sir, I came to keep her company till you cou'd come ac∣cording to your assignation.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Say rather, Madam, that you came to meet Sir Charles Winlove—that this lady is the confederate of your falshood, and that you have mis∣taken this apartment for another.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo,
SP.P: How, Don Philip! I never saw such assu∣ance in my life!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I find my suspicions are not so groundless as I just now believ'd 'em to be— But you shall see my good-nature is not to be im∣pos'd upon.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So! this is excellently fine indeed!—first, to bring strange ladies to my father's house, and then to turn the fault upon me.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Why, Madam, can you deny that this lady came here with you?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, I can—You know, that she did not.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nor did not you come here to meet the English cavalier?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: I won't satisfy you, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Sir, what have you done? I expected Sir Charles here; and instead of that, you are come and have incens'd the governour's daughter to my ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Ha! then I have been too rash indeed!— I find now, that this is the lady I look'd for, and jealousy has brought Leonora hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So, his countenance tells me, he begins to soften to my wish—I see her stratagem has took.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: What shall I say to her?
Madam. I find already I have been in an error in my suspicions, but not in being false myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So! now you see your assurance won't take, you'd endeavour to conceal your falshood.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Madam, I can immediately clear my∣self of that—for to satisfy you who this lady is—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, I am not so passionately in love, a to desire satisfaction.

DIV4.STAGE: Enter Flora through the other door.

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: Madam, I cou'd not find the key before, or—

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Hist, Flora; no more!

SP.SPEAKER: Flo.
SP.P: I find I shall do mischief if I talk.— Madam, your father's coming with another cava∣lier.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Prithee, Leonora, hear me justify my∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: No, I'll relate it all to my lord, and as I never lov'd you, shall be glad of this opportunity to be rid of you—Excellently come off!

DIV4.P: Enter Lorenzo, Sir Charles, and Aspin.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Ha! what's the matter daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: My father, and the English cavalier! I am certainly betray'd again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: His daughter! I am strangely deceiv'd then—for I am sure this is the lady that was taken with me.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Speak, Leonora.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Your lordship shou'd ask that gentleman, who makes private assignations, and brings strange ladies to your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: How, Don Philip!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Pardon me, Sir Charles, for impeach∣ing you—But 'egad, all must out—This lady is the captive, and came here to see my friend, who was to have met her by stealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: That lady the captive!—Now wou'd they, tho' I see her in my presence, persuade me I am blind, and change her to another person.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sir Charles, you seem still to remain in the dark—Pray, Madam, UNVEIL—Now is it Fide∣lia or no?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Ha! I am thunder-struck!—Sure 'tis the fond error of my eyes!—

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: What say you now, Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: And yet, methinks, I cannot be de∣ceiv'd —Is it my Fidelia then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Oh, Sir Charles!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
It is, it is!—The music of her voice informs me now 'tis she!—Oh, my Fidelia!
me fly with joy into thy arms, and breathe my soul upon thy lips.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Long have I wish'd, Sir Charles, for such a happy meeting!—but past misfortunes wou'd be an unwelcome theme—your love will recompense 'em—Be constant for the future, and 'tis all I ask.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: No chance, but death, shall ever part us more!—Sure I am lost in transport and sur∣prize! —Oh, my Fidelia! methinks I cou'd re∣peat thy name, till distant waters catch the charm∣ing echo, and when they rowl high in their moun∣tain-waves, resound it to the skies!

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Nay, amongst all your adventures I think I never saw you in such raptures before.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: Pardon me, friends, if all my senses are o'ercome with joy and admiration!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: This is pleasant indeed! Sir Charles—that you shou'd contrive to see the lady, and yet not know she was here before.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: My lord, Sir Charles is a cavalier for the ladies—and such ever esteem secrecy as a point of honour:—therefore, you must excuse him for his reasons.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P:
Ha! now I begin to understand this mystery!—Fidelia has given me a hint of my in∣constancy—
but I must conceal my affairs with the other lady from the company.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Is the riddle explain'd to your satisfaction, Sir Charles?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: It is, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: So, I see he has taken the hint—Well, tho' I have lost my lover, I shall preserve my honour, that's one comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Asp.
SP.P: Now, I believe by the joy of my master, and the humour of this company, that all is like to go well:—if so, 'tis the first good accident that ever I knew a woman the occasion of.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Now, to add to the pleasures you receive—know, I have this morning had notice from Madrid, that the cavalier who was thought to have been kill'd, is perfectly recover'd of his wounds.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: This is happy indeed!—for methinks, my Fidelia, I would not have the stain of blood fully my character, nor a melancholy thought amidst the the joys of love.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Sir Charles, you must grant me the favour of solemnizing your marriage at my house, with these that are to be coupled also.

SP.SPEAKER: D. Phil.
SP.P: Shall I then, Madam, have the happi∣ness of a reconciliation at last?

SP.SPEAKER: Leo.
SP.P: Aye, Don Philip—for as this affair has been carry'd on by quarrels, I think it may naturally end in marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: Now there is nothing wanting, to com∣pleat our blessing, but a reconciliation with my father.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: That, Madam, I hope is in my power to gain you; for know, that the lord Alonzo is now in my house.

SP.SPEAKER: Fide.
SP.P: What! in Valencia, my lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Yes, Madam—but here he comes!—re∣tire at a distance, and you shall see me break this affair to him.—

DIV4.STAGE: [The company retire to the back-part of the stage.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: So, my lord! I have seen Sir Charles Win∣love, according to my promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Well, and what does he say? How does he behave himself?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: As I expected, my lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: As you expected! Humph! that is, I sup∣pose, you have told him the news of the cavalier's recovery; and now he very peremptorily bids , and intends to march off with my daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Still you won't comprehend me.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Lord, I tell you, I do comprehend you! Don't I know that he is a very bloody-minded fel∣low? Has he not stole away my daughter, and for ought I know riffled her of all?—and this I can't comprehend, forsooth!

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: You won't hear me—

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Nay, I tell you, I do hear you—but I'll not be so impos'd upon I am resolv'd—A pen and ink there! Since the law won't do me justice, I'll write the dog a challenge, and you shall be the bearer.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: A very pretty office for a magistrate indeed! but suppose he shou'd submit to your own terms?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Why let him—My terms are sword and pistol, tell him so!—Odd, tho' I am an old fellow, I can still take a breathing upon occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Nay, since I can't satisfy you myself, I have another card to play.—Come forward there.

DIV4.STAGE: [The company approach, Sir Charles Winlove and Fidelia kneel.
DIV4.P: Now will you be brought to reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Ha! what's the meaning of all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Lor.
SP.P: Speak to him, Madam.
My lord! consider I am your daughter, and forgive my weakness.

SP.SPEAKER: Alon.
SP.P: Hmph!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Cha.
SP.P: My lord, we only want your blessing to compleat our happiness!
